content:
This happens when the profile is not where Thunderbird expects to see it. Thunderbird looks at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini for the location of the profile. The error message indicates that the profiles.ini has been changed or that the profile isn't where it was when backed up. This may happen if copied to drive prior to installing thunderbird. If all is intact, you should be able to - install thunderbird first - copy the folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird (with prompt for overwrites)

Another option is to delete the folder and restart Thunderbird and click tools>import>import from another installation and then select the explicit profile.
creator: davidsk

content: I believe the problem isn't the profile, it is the profiles.ini file that you are importing. - start thunderbird - click tools>import>import from another thunderbird installation - click choose a profile at this point, locate the profile in your backup that is at ...appdata\roaming\thunerbird\profile\<profilename> where 'profile name' is the 11gb one (there may be more than one profile in the .... thunderbird\profiles folder) Doing it this way causes Thunderbird to update the profiles.ini properly.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you so much David, importing everything ultimately worked.

This is what I did:

-installed Thunderbird (same version as source) on target (new Win11 computer) -did not create a profile -mapped %AppData%/Roaming/Thunderbird as a remote drive from old (Win10) computer -imported everything (Tools->Import) from mapped drive/Profiles/*.Default User directory (in my case "t1Djir79.Default User" -Thunderbird copied everything over cleanly -And it restarted upon completion.

Thank you again,
creator: vladd2

content: I am very pleased that all worked out okay. :)

content: Are you sending from a gmail or outlook.com/hotmail/live account? Those services automatically copy sent messages to the Sent Mail or Sent folder, so you must uncheck 'Place a copy in' in the Copies & Folders section of Account Settings.

content:
Hello David, Many thanks for your quick reply. Your question regarding 'columns'. When reading my emails I am looking at two 'columns': the first gives me the details of my email addresses and, underneath, the various Files are listed. The second 'column' is either the emails Inbox/Sent box.

Usually,when filing emails, I use the right-click method. Other times when, say, there are several to move to the same file, I use drag & drop between the columns which is usually successful. The same success for both Inbox/Sent emails.

This week the snag has occured with both Inbox/Sent i.e. that drag & drop removes an email but does not deliver it to the appointed file. Similarly with right-click: the emails it does move do not stay in the files, they quickly go missing.

Hope this clarifies the snag.

Kind regards, Tim

content:
patriciacravener said
New "feature" since last update 102.10.0 (64-bit): Some, but not all, new/incoming messages are marked with a gold diamond or star icon.

I think it was since version 3 your meant, it is certainly not a new feature.

It is a minor problem, but annoying. How can I stop Thunderbird from doing that?

That star indicates that this is the mail in the list that caused the folder name to change colour as having new unread mail in it which you have not had a chance to see. It is also removed as soon as you move to another folder as you have now seen the new and unread mail.

Note new and unseen is in addition to unread. I have thousands of unread mail in some of my folders, but very few are new since I was last in the folder. I also ass the folder name of folders with "unseen" mail in them in blue and having the same gold star attached to their corner. This also changers when I move to another folder.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The somewhat 'official' recommendation is to upgrade in steps, i.e., 68, 78, 91, 102, as that allows each initial release to do its housekeeping. But many just take the jump. Regardless of the approach, please be sure to have a full backup of profile, done when Thunderbird is NOT running. Very important. - If you take the jump to ver 102 and local folders are missing, you can 

  - exit thunderbird   - in Windows File Explorer, copy the Local Folders folder from old profile to Mail/ folder in new profile   - and restart windows

- your old addressbook is in mab format. to convert to sqlite format, use tools>import>import from a file and follow path to select the mab import and the select your mab file in old profile.
creator: davidsk

content:
Right-click the account you wish to backup, select the ImportExportTools NG option then choose Export all the folders (with structure). Choose a destination and you're done.

Note, however, that the ImportExportTools NG add-on will use the local copy/cache of folders and messages as the source for export. This means, if there is a message or folder on the Gmail server, that is NOT locally cached on your computer, then that folder or message will not be included in the export operation and your backup won't be complete. To avoid this, you should first make sure Thunderbird is fully in sync by going to the File menu > Offline > Download/Sync Now. Depending on how much data Thunderbird has to fetch from Gmail, it may take a long time for the synchronization process to complete because of bandwidth limits imposed on Gmail by Google.
creator: stancestans
